summary: On September 21, 2017, the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida entered a final judgment in favor of The Addictions Academy, LLC, a Florida company that provides addiction treatment services in person and via the internet.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Miami-Dade County, Florida, alleges that, between May 13 and May 25, 2015, Robert Nicholl, a resident of Orange County, California, and David Brown, a Kansas resident, made false and misleading statements in a closed Facebook group that targeted Florida residents.  According to the complaint, Appellees' allegedly defamatory statements were directed at Florida residents and entities, including members of a Florida-based addiction treatment organization.  In addition, the complaint alleges that the defendants did not have sufficient minimum contacts with Florida to qualify for a court-ordered exemption under the federal antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, the defendants have consented to the entry of final judgments that permanently enjoin them from violating the federal securities laws, order them to pay disgorgement of $2,101.83 in ill-gotten gains plus interest, and impose a civil penalty of $100,000.  Additionally, the court granted the defendants' motion for a temporary restraining order against further violations of the federal anti-fraud provisions, and ordered the defendants to pay civil penalties in the amount of $1,000 each.  On September 26, 2016, the SEC filed a second amended complaint, this time against Nicholl and Brown, alleging that they violated the federal registration provisions of Sections 5(a), 5(c), and 17(a)(2) and (3) of Florida's long-arm statute, and that they had violated the registration provisions under Section 13(b)(2)(A) and 13(c)(3) thereunder of the state securities laws.  This amended complaint also alleges that Nicholl violated the mandatory reporting provision of Section 5 of the Florida securities laws and that Brown violated the reporting provision under Section 12 of the Exchange Act and Rules 12b-20, 13a-1, and 13b2-2 thereunder, and aiding and abetting violations of Section 13 of the Commission on Securities and Exchange Act Section 12(a) and Rule 13b3-1 thereunder and the reporting provisions of Rule 13d-1 and 13c-3 thereunder under Sections 206(1), 206(2), and 206(4)-8 of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 and Rule 206(3)-8 thereunder; and that the complaint seeks permanent injunctions, civil penalties, disgorg
